docs.abstract: If South Asia cannot work together on shared natural resources, it will be ill equipped to cope with the rush of climate change refugees.
docs.snippet: If South Asia cannot work together on shared natural resources, it will be ill equipped to cope with the rush of climate change refugees.
docs.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — After two weeks of flooding, about half of Bangladesh is under water, 140 people have been killed, tens of thousands of families have been forced from their homes and well over a million acres of crops have been destroyed. The poorest, their rural livelihoods in ruins, will most likely have no choice but to head to the cities.

headline.main: In Bangladesh, a Flood and an Efficient Response
headline.print_headline: A flood and an efficient response in Bangladesh

docs.abstract: In the Natore District in northwest Bangladesh, children attend school on a boat. Flooding is an increasing problem in the country, which is a delta formed by the confluence of major rivers and highly vulnerable to climate change.
docs.snippet: In the Natore District in northwest Bangladesh, children attend school on a boat. Flooding is an increasing problem in the country, which is a delta formed by the confluence of major rivers and highly vulnerable to climate change.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the Natore District in northwest Bangladesh, children attend school on a boat. Flooding is an increasing problem in the country, which is a delta formed by the confluence of major rivers and highly vulnerable to climate change.

byline.original: By Evan Wexler, Ismail Ferdous, Veda Shastri and Kaitlyn Mullin

docs.abstract: Flooding and landslides resulting from monsoon rains have directly affected at least 41 million people in Bangladesh, India and Nepal, the United Nations says.
docs.snippet: Flooding and landslides resulting from monsoon rains have directly affected at least 41 million people in Bangladesh, India and Nepal, the United Nations says.
docs.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — More than 1,000 people have died in floods across South Asia this summer, and as sheets of incessant rain pummeled the vast region on Tuesday, worries grew that the death toll would rise along with the floodwaters.

headline.main: More Than 1,000 Died in South Asia Floods This Summer
headline.print_headline: South Asia Floods Leave Over 1,000 Dead

docs.abstract: The new settlements will be built in the next 10 days on 2,000 acres near the border to house the thousands who have fled from Myanmar, officials said.
docs.snippet: The new settlements will be built in the next 10 days on 2,000 acres near the border to house the thousands who have fled from Myanmar, officials said.
docs.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Bangladesh, facing an unprecedented influx of ethnic Rohingya, plans to build a vast camp to house about 400,000 refugees who have poured into the country over the past three weeks.

headline.main: Bangladesh Plans to Build Huge Refugee Camp for Rohingya
headline.print_headline: Bangladesh to Build Huge Camp for the Rohingya

docs.abstract: Hamidur Rashid had obtained a special visa for the employee after submitting a signed contract to the United Nations, but a federal complaint says he then had her sign a much lower-paying deal.
docs.snippet: Hamidur Rashid had obtained a special visa for the employee after submitting a signed contract to the United Nations, but a federal complaint says he then had her sign a much lower-paying deal.
docs.lead_paragraph: A United Nations economist was arrested on Tuesday on charges that he brought a household worker from Bangladesh to New York, where he underpaid and overworked her and also took steps to cover up his scheme.

headline.main: U.N. Economist Charged With Underpaying Household Worker From Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: U.N. Worker Is Charged In Fleecing Of Home Aide

byline.original: By Benjamin Weiser and Somini Sengupta

docs.abstract: Revisions sought by Islamic scholars were barely noticeable to the public, but intellectuals see them as government accommodation of a larger shift toward radical Islam.
docs.snippet: Revisions sought by Islamic scholars were barely noticeable to the public, but intellectuals see them as government accommodation of a larger shift toward radical Islam.
docs.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Bangladesh’s Education Ministry was preparing to print the 2017 editions of its standard Bengali textbooks when a group of conservative Islamic religious scholars demanded the removal of 17 poems and stories they deemed “atheistic.”

headline.main: To Secular Bangladeshis, Textbook Changes Are a Harbinger
headline.print_headline: A Turn to Islam in Bangladesh

byline.original: By Ellen Barry and Julfikar Ali Manik

docs.abstract: People from Britain to Bangladesh are paying a price for unabated climate change.
docs.snippet: People from Britain to Bangladesh are paying a price for unabated climate change.
docs.lead_paragraph: Houston isn’t the only major city reeling from record rainfall and devastating floods. In Mumbai, India, where summer monsoons are annual events, as much rain fell in 12 hours on Tuesday as normally does over 11 days in a typical monsoon, paralyzing the city, India’s financial capital.

docs.abstract: Adam Dean and Tomas Munita, two photographers whose work appears regularly in The New York Times, describe their coverage of the crisis in Myanmar and Bangladesh.
docs.snippet: Adam Dean and Tomas Munita, two photographers whose work appears regularly in The New York Times, describe their coverage of the crisis in Myanmar and Bangladesh.
docs.lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, Adam Dean and Tomas Munita, two photographers whose work appears regularly in The Times, describe their coverage of the Rohingya crisis in Myanmar and Bangladesh.

headline.main: A Desperate Trek Toward Misery and Resignation: Capturing the Plight of the Rohingya
headline.print_headline: Capturing the Plight of the Rohingya

byline.original: By Adam Dean and Tomas Munita

docs.abstract: Roughly two-thirds of the Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar fled this year as soldiers shot them, raped them and torched their homes.
docs.snippet: Roughly two-thirds of the Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar fled this year as soldiers shot them, raped them and torched their homes.
docs.lead_paragraph: Roughly two-thirds of the Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar fled this year as soldiers shot them, raped them and torched their homes.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

byline.original: By Tomas Munita, Ben C. Solomon, Mona El-Naggar and Adam Dean

docs.abstract: An announcement by Myanmar and Bangladesh brings a vague commitment to return migrants who fled death and destruction in a military crackdown.
docs.snippet: An announcement by Myanmar and Bangladesh brings a vague commitment to return migrants who fled death and destruction in a military crackdown.
docs.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Myanmar and Bangladesh said Thursday that they had moved one step closer to the possible repatriation of hundreds of thousands of Rohingya who have fled Myanmar for Bangladesh over the past three months.

headline.main: Deal on Rohingya Repatriation Inches Forward, but Hurdles Remain
